awd_titl_txt: Environmental Stewardship of Indigenous Lands Scholarship Program
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the Environmental Stewardship of Indigenous Lands (ESIL) Scholarship Program will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  Over five years, the project will fund 16 scholarships to students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in Biology, Civil Engineering, or Environmental Science at the University of Colorado Denver. The ESIL Scholarship Program will provide support, mentoring, and training in environmental stewardship in collaboration with Indigenous peoples (American Indian, Alaska Native and Native Hawaiian). 

The ESIL Scholarship Program will address the need for environmental tribal liaisons, individuals trained in both STEM and cross-cultural communication. To meet this need, the ESIL Scholarship Program will enable scholarship recipients to complete internships at tribal and non-tribal government partners, and to participate in extracurricular activities designed to provide cross-cultural awareness in STEM, academic supports, and professional development. The ESIL Scholarship Program has the potential to produce valuable knowledge about: (1) how a university can promote equity for all students, and (2) how non-technical training in culture, professionalism, and communication can reduce barriers to retention in STEM programs (e.g., the perceived need to abandon one's cultural identity in favor of a new scientific dominant-culture identity). The ESIL Scholarship Program will conduct research on how to provide programming grounded in the viewpoint that cultural identity and scientific identity are symbiotic rather than exclusive. The research will be carried out via both quantitative and qualitative research methods. The ESIL Scholarship Program aims to increase enrollment in STEM majors interested in environmental stewardship, improve graduation rates of STEM students, and strengthen Indigenous culture on a collegiate campus through deeper connections with tribal and government partners. The project will develop a unique model for synergizing indigenous culture and STEM through cross-cultural experiences and will train students who will be uniquely qualified for STEM careers in land stewardship.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
OVERVIEW

Since 2018, the University of Colorado Denver (CU Denver) has offered a first-of-its-kind program to prepare students majoring in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) to liaise on environmental issues between tribal and non-tribal organizations. This program, called Environmental Stewardship of Indigenous Lands (ESIL), offers a transcripted academic certificate that requires four elements: (1) mentorship, (2) coursework, (3) workshops, and (4) internships. Through award 1742603, from 2018-2024, STEM majors enrolled in the ESIL certificate program and meeting certain eligibility requirements could apply for scholarships funded by a U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF) program called Scholarships in STEM (S-STEM). This report summarizes the goals and results of that S-STEM award.

GOALS

Our funded proposal had two goals:

1. Provide an integrated recruitment, support, and placement program, comprising curricular and extracurricular activities, for STEM students interested in working as tribal liaisons.

2. Research gaps in the STEM education literature related to achievement, cultural navigation, and establishing symbiotic cultural and scientific identities.

During the six year period of our S-STEM award, we have substantially accomplished both of these goals. We supported students, engaged tribal and government partners, centered Indigenous STEM, and shared lessons learned in refereed papers and conferences. Importantly, this award also prepared ESIL to guide the Native Food, Energy, and Water Systems (FEWS) Alliance to develop its own Native FEWS Certificate that premiered in Fall 2024.

BROADER IMPACTS

Our first goal was to "provide an integrated recruitment, support, and placement program, comprising curricular and extracurricular activities, for STEM students interested in working as tribal liaisons." Since our first students joined in 2018, we have engaged 25 students in the ESIL program, 11 of whom received S-STEM scholarship support. These 25 students have participated in 30 workshops and 11 internships with numerous tribal, government, and private sector partners. Almost all of our S-STEM scholars are now working as STEM professionals or are on track to graduate in STEM, which explains why student feedback has been overwhelmingly positive. On all these counts, we have substantially achieved our first goal.

ESIL's impact is largely through its alumni. ESIL's growing list of alumni are entering the workforce or advanced academic training with awareness, experience, and perspective on Indigenous lands that are not often included in STEM curricula. As the program continues to develop, these alumni may provide the most impactful outcome of this work.

In addition, ESIL has demonstrated the possibility of a multifaceted academic certificate program. Before the ESIL certificate, academic certificates at CU Denver typically required the successful completion of a certain number of related courses. In contrast, the ESIL certificate was multifaceted, still requiring courses, but also requiring mentoring, workshops, and an internship. In this way, ESIL has been a model certificate at CU Denver, supporting our goal of becoming the nation’s first equity-serving institution.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Our second goal was to "research gaps in the STEM education literature related to achievement, cultural navigation, and establishing symbiotic cultural and scientific identities." This research has been reported in four archival peer-reviewed journal articles (including one currently under review) that are, or will be, available through the NSF Public Access Repository (NSF-PAR). Here we provide key lessons learned from each of these studies:

1. Velez et al. (2022), published as an Editor’s Choice in the journal Evaluation and Program Planning, explained how we applied the Indigenous evaluation framework to provide ongoing feedback on our administration of the ESIL scholarship program. In brief, we found that evaluation based on relationships, listening, and learning can generate more honest feedback and eliminate blind spots.

2. Rice and Mays (2022), published in the journal Advances in Engineering Education, contrasted one Indigenous perspective (from Rice) and one non-Indigenous perspective (from Mays) on Garrison Dam on the Missouri River. Through these contrasting perspectives, the paper challenges engineering faculty to consider that many students have a broader perspective that includes both technical details and the social and environmental impacts of engineering.

3. Mays et al. (2024), accepted on August 2, 2024 by the journal Advances in Engineering Education, provides an overview of the ESIL program. This paper identifies factors that bring students into the program, aspects of their experience within the program, and shows how the ESIL program has provided safe space for students to engage in Indigenous worldviews within the context of STEM degree programs.

4. Mays et al. (2025), submitted to an archival peer-reviewed journal on September 24, 2024, summarizes lessons learned from ESIL workshops and internships. Student feedback indicates that these activities complement students’ education and training by enhancing their wayfinding, knowledge acquisition, perspective taking, and engagement with Indigenous cultures, knowledge, and practice. These complementary factors underscore the importance of culturally tailored education and strong partnerships with Indigenous professionals and communities to prepare the next generation of Tribal Liaisons.
